stem: The nurse is assessing a 9-month-old infant during a well-child visit. Based on the provided information, for each assessment finding, indicate the age range at which the finding is considered developmentally appropriate.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
09:00 SBAR for Patient: Baby Michael
Situation: Michael is a 9-month-old male here for a routine well-child visit.
Background: Mother reports an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. Michael is up-to-date on vaccinations. He is primarily breastfed with some introduction to pureed foods. No known allergies.
Assessment: Vitals stable (see Vitals tab). Physical exam reveals a healthy, active infant. He is able to sit unsupported and is beginning to crawl. He babbles frequently but does not yet say specific words. He demonstrates stranger anxiety and reaches for his mother when approached. He is able to transfer objects from one hand to the other. He is currently teething; mother reports increased drooling and irritability.
Plan: Continue to monitor growth and development. Reinforce anticipatory guidance regarding nutrition, safety, and upcoming developmental milestones. Administer scheduled vaccinations. Discuss sleep patterns and address any parental concerns. Schedule next well-child visit at 12 months. Provide resources for early intervention services if needed. Emphasize importance of a safe home environment to prevent falls and injuries as mobility increases. Encourage continued interaction and play to promote cognitive and social development. Provide written materials regarding age-appropriate activities to stimulate development. Answer all questions and address concerns.
Signed, RN

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content:
08:50: HR 120 bpm, RR 30, Temp 37.2C, SpO2 98%
09:00: HR 118 bpm, RR 28, Temp 37.1C, SpO2 99%
09:10: HR 115 bpm, RR 26, Temp 37.0C, SpO2 99%

tabs.title: Lab Results
tabs.content:
Hemoglobin: 11.5 g/dL
Hematocrit: 34.5%
White blood cell count: 8,000/mm3

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
General: Alert and active infant in no acute distress.
Skin: Warm, dry, and intact. No rashes or lesions.
HEENT: Normocephalic. Fontanelles soft and flat. TMs clear bilaterally. Mucous membranes moist. Two lower incisors present. Increased drooling noted.
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally. No retractions or wheezes.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, and non-distended. Bowel sounds present in all four quadrants.
Musculoskeletal: Moves all extremities equally. Demonstrates good muscle tone. Able to sit unsupported. Beginning to crawl.
Neurological: Alert and responsive. Demonstrates appropriate reflexes. Transfers objects from one hand to the other. Demonstrates stranger anxiety.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
Administer scheduled vaccinations per protocol.
Provide anticipatory guidance regarding nutrition, safety, and development.
Monitor growth and development.
Schedule follow-up appointment at 12 months.

rows.text: Transfers objects from one hand to the other

rationale.correct: All options selected align with the expected developmental milestones for the indicated ages. Accurate assessment and interpretation of these milestones are crucial for identifying potential developmental delays and implementing appropriate interventions.
rationale.incorrect: The selected options do not align with the expected developmental milestones for the indicated ages. A thorough understanding of developmental milestones is essential for providing appropriate care and anticipatory guidance to parents.

answerBreakdown.rationale: Sitting unsupported typically develops around 6 months of age. This indicates good trunk control and balance.

answerBreakdown.text: Transfers objects from one hand to the other
answerBreakdown.rationale: Transferring objects from one hand to the other usually occurs between 6-12 months. This demonstrates developing fine motor skills and coordination.

Stranger anxiety typically emerges between 6-12 months as infants become more aware of familiar faces and exhibit distress when approached by unfamiliar individuals. This is a normal part of social and emotional development.

clinicalPearls: Developmental milestones provide a framework for assessing a child's progress, but there is a normal range for achievement. Individual variations are common.
Early identification of developmental delays allows for timely intervention and support to optimize a child's developmental trajectory.
Parents should be encouraged to actively participate in their child's development through play, interaction, and stimulation.

questionTrap.trap: Confusing the order of milestone achievement is a common error. For instance, assuming that stranger anxiety occurs before sitting unsupported is incorrect.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Review the typical sequence of developmental milestones and understand the approximate age ranges for each achievement.

mnemonic.title: SMART Milestones
mnemonic.expansion: S: Sitting unsupported (6 months), M: Manipulating objects (6-12 months), A: Anxiety with strangers (6-12 months), R: Reaching for objects (4 months), T: Talking (12 months).
